Dear Kari Ann Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/6 or 5/7, Youth S chose to nap in his room and was
assaulted by an unidentified youth who left bruises and scratches
on his face. Staff were not aware this happened so did not
intervene.
Investigation On 5/10/23, I interviewed Complainant, who is also the
Community Management Organization (CMO) Worker. She said
she visited Youth S on 5/9/23 and saw scratches and yellowish
bruises under his eyes. Youth S told Complainant that Youth 2,
who he refused to identify, hit him in his bedroom on 5/6/23 or
5/7/23 (weekend) while Staff 1 was supposed to be supervising
the youths. Youth S did not tell anyone this happened until 5/9/23.
Complainant questioned the level of supervision at the facility but
had no additional concerns.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I collaborated with Government Worker 1 via phone. She said an
on-call government worker completed a well-being check on
Youth S on 5/9/23 and forwarded a photo of his injuries taken the
same date. The photo shows yellowish-brown bruising and
patchy redness under his right eye and a purple mark under his
left eye.
I notified Chief Administrator (CA) of the investigation via email
and Director of the allegation via phone. Director said she would
move Youth S to another pod for his safety, have him examined
by the nurse and review video footage of dayshift on 5/6/23 when
the identified staff worked. After reviewing the video, Director said
nothing shows one or two youths entering or exiting Youth S’s
room. However, she said there was video of Youth S
horseplaying with other youths.
I interviewed Youth S at the facility on 5/10/23. He is not a reliable
witness as he told various adults different accounts of what
2

happened. After the facility became aware of the allegation,
Youth S said he was moved to another pod and “feels better.” He
said the incident happened inside his room on Pod E between
lunch and dinner while Staff 1 and 3 were working. He thought it
happened on 5/6/23 or 5/7/23 but he was “not 100% sure.”
Before the incident, Youth S said the youths were in the general
area playing games while he sat alone on the outskirts. Youth 1,
who he refused to identify, accused Youth S of calling him a
“bitch.” “I went to my room to excuse myself.” Youth 3 asked
Youth S to bring a deck of cards out from his room. Youth S got
the cards and as he turned to exit his room, he said Youth 2, who
he also refused to identify, was in his room and punched him once
in each eye with his fist. “I swung back, hit his chest, and
slammed him onto the floor.” Youth 3, who he refused to identify
as well, came inside Youth S’ room and “broke it up.” “Youth 3
grabbed me off of Youth 2 and then walked Youth 2 out of my
room.” Youth S said he was seen by a nurse for his injuries on
5/9/23 and did not require any medical treatment.
I asked if Youth S was horseplaying with the other youths as seen
on video by Director. He said he did not recall horseplaying but
admitted he “plays” with Youth M and C. Youth S said Youths M
and C were not involved in this incident. I asked Youth S where
Staff 1 and 3 were when this incident occurred. He guessed Staff
1 was in the control room and Staff 3 was on a bathroom break.
To avoid being called a “snitch” and getting “jumped” again, Youth
S said he did not tell Staff 1, 3 or any other staff that this
happened. I asked Youth S if bedroom doors are supposed to be
locked when youths are outside of their rooms. He said “Yes, but
sometimes they aren’t.”
Director said there is no policy at the facility that room doors must
be locked when youth are outside their rooms. However, Director,
Staff 1 and Staff 3 agreed it is best practice that the doors are
locked at all times.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1. She has
only worked at the facility for two months. Staff 1 said she saw
Youth S on 5/6/23 and did not observe any injuries on his face.
She denied seeing another youth go into Youth S’s room but
acknowledged the other youths “pick on” him. “They smack each
other on the backs of their necks (referred to as cheese-neck) so I
pay close attention to Youth S.” Staff 1 said there are always at
least two staff supervising the youths in the general area when
they are out of their rooms. “One of us can go briefly to the staff
3

office. Staff bathroom breaks require another staff to cover in their
absence.”
I asked Staff 1 if the bedroom doors are supposed to be locked
when youths are outside their rooms. She stated their doors are
supposed to be locked, but “residents use the rules against us.”
Staff 1 explained that youths will ask staff to unlock their doors to
use the bathroom. Multiple youths ask consecutively knowing it is
difficult for the staff to track each youth’s whereabouts and assure
their doors are locked when they exit. She said youths also warn
staff they will get “in trouble” if staff deny them use of their
bathroom. This manipulation tactic set up by the youths results in
unlocked doors where one or more youths can slip out of line of
sight of the staff as well as the cameras.
Given Youth S’ inability and/or unwillingness to provide accurate
information, Government Worker 1 and I were unable to determine
who, where, when or how Youth S got two black eyes. The fact
his injuries were nearly healed by 5/8/23 suggests they may have
happened in one of many previously documented altercations he
had with other youths. Nonetheless Government Worker 1 and I
reviewed video footage of Pod E between lunch and dinner on
5/6/23.
Video cameras at Lincoln Center do not have audio capabilities.
Video shows several youths sitting in a wide circle on Pod E with
Staff 2 and 3 supervising the group. During the two-hour period
reviewed, a number of youths are seen walking up to or behind
Youth S throwing “stress balls” at him that hit him on various parts
of his body. One youth touches Youth S’s hair and rubs his head.
Other youths smack him on the back of his neck while Youth S
covers his head and remains seated in his chair. One youth
approaches Youth S and swings at his face. Neither Staff 2 nor 3
physically intervene. It is unknown if the staff intervened verbally
or issued misconduct write-ups to any youths for these behaviors.
At the end of the period, Youth J is seen moving toward his own
room. Youth S moves in the same direction and a crowd of
youth’s gather outside the room. Staff 2 arrives at the room within
seconds and the youths disperse. It could not be determined
whether Youth J and S were inside or outside of the room given
the camera angle.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for two months. Staff 2 said the youths “like
to pick on Youth S. I made it clear I’d write them up for assaulting
a peer.” Staff 2 was asked about the point in the video where
4

youths were gathered outside a room and Staff 2 intervened. He
recalled, “One kid asked me to get something from the control
room.” Looking back on this, Staff 2 felt this request was an
intentional manipulation to distract his attention away from the
youths on the pod. “Lots of kids standing around (a room) drew
me there. I saw Youth S and J inside the room. I got them out.
That’s why it’s important we keep all the room door closed.” Staff
2 denied seeing Youth S and J fighting.
I asked Staff 2 about the head-smacking and ball throwing on the
pod. He referred to this behavior as “horseplay” and said it is not
allowed but appeared somewhat helpless to prevent it.
I interviewed Staff 3 jointly with Government Worker 1 via phone
on 6/1/23. When the incident occurred, he had only worked at the
facility for three weeks. Around 5/4/23, Staff 3 recalled he went
into a closet to get a mop. When he came out, he saw Youth S
exiting Youth C’s room and observed Youth S’s face was red.
I asked Staff 3 why Youth C’s room was unlocked. He said he did
not know but “youths find ways to pop the locks using UNO
cards.” Staff 3 denied ever seeing a youth “pop” a lock. He
believes the facility has a policy that bedroom doors must remain
locked when youth are outside of their rooms. Staff 3 checks that
doors are locked all day every day, but said all staff are not as
vigilant as he is. Staff 3 further explained that a red light above
the room door is supposed to signal when a door is unlocked but
some of the lights show red when the door is locked rendering the
system unreliable. He said he has reported the light malfunction
to management.
Staff 3 added that he is frequently mandated to work up to six
hours beyond the end of his regular shift. He said no staff
members want to work on Pod E because it seems youth with the
unruliest behaviors are placed there.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
5

Analysis Staff 3 saw Youths S and C coming out of a bedroom on 5/4/23
and Staff 2 saw Youths S and J coming out of a bedroom on
5/6/23. Unlocked room doors interfere with staff’s ability to
maintain line-of-sight of the youths resulting in supervision/safety
issues in secure juvenile detention and treatment facilities.
CONSULTATION
I provided literature to leaders at the facility on the benefits of
creating a positive peer culture throughout the facility. Strategies
for handling pods with particularly difficult youth should be
developed with increased supervisory and clinical staff presence
and support provided.
Facility leaders should regularly monitor whether or not red lights
above the doors function properly, determine if any youth are
actually able to “pop” their locks, and make door/lock repairs
accordingly.
A written supervision policy/procedure should be developed
requiring all bedroom doors are locked when youth are inside or
outside of their rooms.
I provided consultation on one way that staff can assure all doors
remain locked when youth are outside of their rooms, which is
labor-intensive. Staff should first remind youths to use the
bathroom prior to exiting their rooms for the next activity. Youth
should exit their rooms one at a time with staff checking that each
door locks behind him. Youth should only be allowed to use their
room toilets one at a time, staff should unlock the door and assure
it locks behind him after each entrance and exit. This may require
staff remaining at the door as youth enters and exits.
Staff need to remain alert to the various tactics youths use to
manipulate and control their environment. Needs should only be
met for one youth one at a time. When one staff is meeting a
need, the other staff must be supervising the other youths.
Forming lines arm-distance apart during transport, counting off in
line and standing at ease next to bedroom doors until released to
move by staff are other ways to add structure to the milieu.
Essential rules/codes of conduct could be posted on each pod to
remind youth of prohibited behaviors such as no touching other
youths, no head-smacking, no horseplay, no bullying, no name-
calling, and no entering a room without staff awareness and
permission.
6

To specifically discourage horseplay and bullying, staff should
physically move to the area where the horseplay is occurring and
provide continuous verbal redirection and protection to any youth
being bullied. Staff may suggest the bullied youth voluntarily rest
safely in his room. If a youth requests to voluntarily be locked in
his room for safety reasons during free time, that is not considered
seclusion. However, staff must complete eye-on checks of that
youth at variable intervals at least every fifteen minutes and the
checks must be documented. Youth must also be allowed out of
their room when they ask.
Finally, staff should write an unusual incident report upon
discovering two or more youths in a room without staff supervision
or permission.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
